text: Genetic evidence for an additional factor required for <extra_id_0> erythropoietin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced signal transduction .

<extra_id_0> Erythropoietin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> EPO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and its receptor ( <extra_id_0> EPOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) are required for the development of mature erythrocytes .

After binding of ligand , the <extra_id_0> EPOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activates a variety of signaling pathways that ultimately control cellular proliferation , survival , and specific gene expression .

Although erythroid progenitors appear to be the principal <extra_id_0> EPO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - responsive cell type in vivo due to the restricted expression of the <extra_id_0> EPOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , many growth factor - dependent cell lines expressing the <extra_id_0> EPOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can respond to <extra_id_0> EPO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by activating many or all of these pathways .

In the present study , we have identified a cellular context ( the <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ] - dependent HT-2 line ) in which the <extra_id_0> EPO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation of the <extra_id_0> EPOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> fails to support cellular proliferation , <extra_id_0> STAT-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction , or MAPK activation , despite efficient phosphorylation of the <extra_id_0> EPOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> JAK2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and inhibition of apoptosis after withdrawal of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Interestingly , when we fused HT-2 cells expressing the <extra_id_0> EPOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with Ba / F3 cells in a complementation assay , the resulting hybridomas proliferated and potently activated <extra_id_0> STAT-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and MAPK in response to <extra_id_0> EPO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
These data indicate that an unidentified cellular factor is needed to mediate signaling by the <extra_id_0> EPOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Moreover , Ba / F3 cells apparently express this factor ( s ) and somatic fusions can , therefore , confer <extra_id_0> EPO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - responsiveness to HT-2 cells that lack this factor .
